Brown_Rust.symptoms: Small, round to oval, orange-brown pustules scattered mostly on upper leaf surfaces; yellowing and early death of leaves in severe cases.
Brown_Rust.environmentalConditions: Favored by moderate temperatures (15–22°C) and high humidity; dew formation promotes spore germination.

biological: Apply Trichoderma harzianum as foliar spray
Use Pseudomonas fluorescens as seed and foliar treatment
cultural: Timely sowing to escape peak infection period
Grow resistant varieties suited to local conditions

prevention: Use rust-resistant wheat varieties (e.g., PBW 343, HD 2967)
Avoid late sowing to reduce exposure
Brown_Rust.economicThreshold: When 10% or more plants show symptoms during active growth stage
traditionalPractices: Application of wood ash to affected foliage
Planting near windbreaks to limit spore movement
Use of garlic or ginger decoction as natural spray

Yellow_Rust.symptoms: Long yellow stripes of powdery spores on leaves and sheaths; yellowing along veins and early leaf drying.
Yellow_Rust.environmentalConditions: Cool (10–15°C), moist weather with high humidity and prolonged dew periods.
Yellow_Rust.vulnerableStages: Tillering to booting stages, especially in early sown crops.

biological: Apply Bacillus subtilis as foliar spray
Use Pseudomonas fluorescens for seed treatment and field application
cultural: Early sowing to avoid high-risk period
Regular field monitoring and removal of infected plants

prevention: Use resistant wheat varieties (e.g., HD 3086, WH 1105)
Monitor fields regularly during vulnerable growth stages
Yellow_Rust.economicThreshold: When 10% of leaf area or 5% of plants are infected
traditionalPractices: Intercropping with non-host plants to reduce rust spread
Field sanitation and residue destruction (avoid open burning)

Stem Rust.symptoms: Reddish-brown, elongated pustules on stems, leaves, and leaf sheaths; later black pustules form; weakening and lodging of plants
Stem Rust.environmentalConditions: Favored by warm temperatures (25-30°C) with high moisture or dew
Stem Rust.vulnerableStages: From tillering to grain filling stages

cultural: Grow resistant varieties (e.g., Sr31, Sr24 containing lines)
Remove volunteer wheat and grassy weeds

prevention: Monitor fields regularly and spray at first sign
Early sowing to avoid peak rust season
Stem Rust.economicThreshold: When 5% of plants show early rust pustules
traditionalPractices: Use of mixed cropping to reduce rust spread

Loose Smut.symptoms: Dark olive-black spore masses replace the grains; infected heads emerge earlier than healthy ones
Loose Smut.environmentalConditions: Favored by cool, moist weather during flowering

chemical: Seed treatment with Carboxin (37.5% + Thiram 37.5%) at 2g/kg seed
biological: Application of Bacillus subtilis on seeds
cultural: Hot water seed treatment (52°C for 10 minutes)

traditionalPractices: Hot water treatment by farmers using traditional methods

Fusarium Head Blight.symptoms: Bleached spikelets; pink or orange fungal growth at the base of glumes; shriveled grains

chemical: Spray Tebuconazole (25% EC) at early flowering
biological: Application of Trichoderma spp. on heads

Powdery Mildew.symptoms: White, powdery fungal growth on leaves and stems; later turning gray-brown
Powdery Mildew.economicThreshold: When 10% of the leaf area is covered
traditionalPractices: Application of wood ash to control mildew

Septoria_Leaf_Spot.symptoms: Small, dark brown to black lesions with yellow halos on the leaves; premature leaf death.
Septoria_Leaf_Spot.environmentalConditions: Cool, wet conditions (15-20°C) promote disease development.
Septoria_Leaf_Spot.vulnerableStages: From tillering to early grain filling.

cultural: Proper field sanitation and residue management

prevention: Monitor fields regularly and remove infected leaves
Septoria_Leaf_Spot.economicThreshold: When 5% of the leaf area is infected

Septoria Leaf Blotch.symptoms: Small, dark, water-soaked lesions on the leaves, which eventually turn into elongated, dark brown or black streaks; premature leaf death.
Septoria Leaf Blotch.environmentalConditions: Favored by cool, wet conditions (12–18°C) during early wheat growth.
Septoria Leaf Blotch.vulnerableStages: From tillering to flag leaf stages.

biological: Use Trichoderma harzianum as foliar spray
Apply Bacillus subtilis as a seed treatment
cultural: Remove infected crop residues after harvest

Septoria Leaf Blotch.economicThreshold: When 5-10% of the leaf area is infected during the grain-filling stage
traditionalPractices: Application of wood ash on affected areas
